header.title: Medieval Byzantine Magical Amulets and Their Tradition

central_thesis: This paper provides a comprehensive survey and analysis of a distinct group of medieval Byzantine magical amulets (primarily 10th-12th centuries) featuring a 'face surrounded by serpents' motif and the 'hystera formula'. Jeffrey Spier argues that these amulets primarily functioned to control the 'roaming womb' (hystera), based on an ancient textual magical tradition, and are distinct from earlier Graeco-Roman and 6th/7th-century Syrian/Palestinian traditions focused on child-harming demons like Abyzou/Gylou, though elements from both traditions sometimes conflated on individual pieces. The 'face with serpents' is interpreted as a symbolic 'portrait' of the womb itself, used in a magical context to gain power over it.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the 'hystera' amulets, detailing their diverse forms, the central 'face with serpents' motif, and the Greek inscription 'hystera melane melanomene'. It highlights the historical debate among scholars regarding the image's identification, the amulets' origin, and their magical tradition, emphasizing the need for clarification.

structure_content.chapter_title: I. Brief Description of the Amulets
structure_content.summary: Spier categorizes and describes the physical characteristics of the amulets, including lead and bronze pendants, enamel on copper, Russian 'zmeeviki' (serpent-amulets), bronze tokens, and rings. He notes their stylistic and iconographic variations, materials used, and the prevalence of the 'face with serpents' motif, often paired with the 'hystera' formula or Christian imagery like 'rider saints', Christ, or the Virgin.

This section provides a detailed analysis of the core 'hystera formula' ('Womb, black, blackening, as a snake you coil...'), discussing its abbreviations, alternative readings, and additional inscriptions. Other common phrases include Psalm 90, the Trisagion, invocations of Christ, the Virgin, and saints, and blundered divine names. Russian examples often feature Slavonic inscriptions.

Spier argues for a 10th-12th century dating for most of these amulets, citing archaeological contexts (Corinth), stylistic similarities to 11th-century cameos, and the use of enamel and bloodstone, which became prominent in the 10th century. He distinguishes them from earlier 6th/7th-century bronze amulets found in Syria/Palestine, noting their distinct find-spots in Greece, Asia Minor, and Russia, indicating a Middle Byzantine origin.

This section examines the iconographic motifs, particularly the 'rider saint' subduing a female demon (Abyzou/Gylou), tracing its roots in ancient demonological beliefs. Spier critically refutes the theory that the 'face with serpents' derives from the Egyptian deity Chnoubis, instead proposing that this motif directly represents the 'hystera' (womb) itself, acting as a magical 'portrait' for exorcistic control, consistent with ancient beliefs about the 'roaming womb' and its associated ailments.

structure_content.chapter_title: V. The Textual Transmission of the Hystera Formula
structure_content.summary: Spier investigates the historical transmission of the 'hystera formula'. While not found in its complete form in earlier Roman or early Byzantine texts, elements trace back to the 5th century, suggesting a lost prototype. He compares it to similar ancient spells and discusses its widespread use in medieval Europe, Russia, and Jewish magic, noting its transmission through magical handbooks, euchologia, and exorcistic texts, sometimes with corruptions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix I: Catalogue of Medieval Byzantine Amulets
structure_content.summary: A comprehensive catalog detailing specific examples of medieval Byzantine amulets. Each entry describes the material, dimensions, iconography (sides A and B), inscriptions, and provenance. The amulets are grouped by their primary motifs, such as the 'hystera' alone, 'hystera' combined with 'rider saints', or 'hystera' with other Christian iconography.

This appendix describes a distinct group of 6th/7th-century bronze pendant-amulets, primarily from Syria/Palestine. These amulets typically feature a 'rider saint' (e.g., Solomon, Arlaph) spearing a female demon (Abyzou), accompanied by formulae like 'one God who conquers evil' or Psalm 90. Spier explicitly differentiates their iconography and magical function from the later 'hystera' amulets, emphasizing that the 'face with serpents' motif is absent from this earlier group.

A brief update noting the recent discovery of an additional lead pendant-amulet in Constantinople, which further supports the proposed Middle Byzantine dating (c. 1200) and the common pairing of the 'hystera' image with the 'rider saint' motif on these objects.

key_concepts.definition: A specific group of medieval Byzantine magical amulets (10th-12th centuries AD) primarily characterized by a 'face surrounded by serpents' motif and the Greek 'hystera formula'. These amulets were designed to address ailments related to the 'roaming womb'.

The core inscription found on the amulets: 'Υστέρα μελάνη μελανωμένη ὡς ὄφις εἰλύεσαι καὶ ὡς δράκον συρίζησε καὶ ὡς λέων βρυχᾶσαι καὶ ὡς ἀρνίον κοιμοῦ' (Womb, black, blackening, as a snake you coil and as a serpent you hiss and as a lion you roar, and as a lamb, lie down!). This is an exorcistic command aimed at calming the womb and returning it to its proper place, reflecting ancient beliefs in the womb as an animalistic entity.

The central enigmatic image on the 'hystera' amulets, often mistaken for Medusa. Spier argues it functions as a pictorial representation or 'portrait' of the 'hystera' (womb) itself, providing the practitioner magical control over the entity through its image.

Names for female child-harming demons in Byzantine demonology and folklore. They are often depicted on amulets as prostrate figures being subdued by a 'rider saint' or angel. This tradition is largely distinct from the 'hystera' charm, though occasional conflations occur on medieval amulets.

An ancient medical and folkloric belief that the womb is an autonomous, animate creature capable of moving within the female (and sometimes male) body. Its displacement was thought to cause a wide range of ailments, including physical pains, fevers, and mental distress (like hysteria).

A Russian term meaning 'serpent-amulets'. This refers to a series of bronze, silver, and gold amulets of Russian manufacture (11th-12th centuries) that either imitate or are closely related to the Byzantine 'hystera' amulets, often incorporating local iconography and Slavonic inscriptions.

An Egyptian astrological decan, typically depicted as a lion-headed serpent with a radiant mane, associated with healing and protection, particularly of the stomach and womb, primarily found on Graeco-Roman magical gems. Spier refutes the theory that the 'face with serpents' motif of Byzantine amulets derives from Chnoubis due to iconographic and functional discrepancies.

A common iconographic device on Byzantine amulets featuring a saint (e.g., Sisinnios, Michael, George) on horseback, spearing a prostrate female figure, typically representing a demon such as Abyzou/Gylou. This motif is linked to protective magic against specific demonic harms.

Geometric and abstract marks such as pentagrams, star-shaped and N/Z-shaped ring-signs, and crosses that appear on the amulets, often alongside or between inscriptions. These are common elements in magical texts and are employed to reinforce or enhance the magical efficacy of the amulet.

practical_system.description: The practical system described involves the creation and deployment of physical amulets to influence the 'hystera' (womb) and, to a lesser extent, to provide protection against child-harming female demons (Abyzou/Gylou). The core principle relies on the power of inscribed verbal formulae and symbolic iconography, embodying an exorcistic command to the targeted entity.
tools: Amulets (Physical Supports): Various forms, including lead, bronze, silver, and gold pendants (cast or engraved), enamelled copper pendants, die-struck bronze tokens, and rings (silver and bronze) with octagonal hoops and circular bezels. Engraved gems made of bloodstone, jasper, or onyx are also used.

Inscriptions/Formulae: The 'hystera formula' (Υστέρα μελάνη μελανωμένη...), variants of Psalm 90 (91), the Trisagion (ΑΓΙΟΣ ΑΓΙΟΣ ΑΓΙΟC), invocations like 'Lord, help the bearer' (Κύριε βοέθε τὸν φορο[υ]ντα), divine names (Iao, Sabaoth), angelic names (Michael, Gabriel, Raphael, Ouriel, Arlaph), and names of saints (Sisinnios, Boris, Gleb, Niketas).

Iconography: The 'face with serpents' motif, 'rider saint' spearing a prostrate female demon, busts of Christ and the Virgin, standing saints (e.g., St Anne, imperial figures), and symbolic elements such as crosses, stars, crescents, pentagrams, and various 'ring-signs' (e.g., Z-shaped, N-shaped).

Materials: Lead, bronze, silver, gold, copper, onyx, agate, jasper, and bloodstone. The choice of material may carry specific magical associations or reflect the socio-economic status of the wearer and the craftsman.
rituals: Inscription/Engraving: The central operative act involves precisely engraving or casting specific magical formulae, divine names, angelic names, and saintly invocations onto durable materials. This act likely involved ritualistic recitation or intent during the amulet's creation.
Wearing/Carrying: Amulets are designed for continuous proximity to the wearer, typically on the body, to exert their protective or commanding influence over the 'hystera' or to repel demonic forces.

Invocation/Command: The formulae inscribed on the amulets function as direct commands or invocations. The 'hystera formula' explicitly commands the womb to 'lie down' and 'be calm,' while other inscriptions invoke divine or angelic assistance, or command demons to 'flee'.
Binding: Some formulae incorporate explicit references to 'binding' (dedemeni), suggesting a magical act intended to immobilize or restrain the roaming womb.

Sympathetic Magic (Portraiture): The 'face with serpents' motif is theorized to serve as a 'portrait' of the hystera, allowing the practitioner to gain power over the entity through its symbolic representation on the amulet.

relevant_quotes.text: Υστέρα μελάνη μελανωμένη ὡς ὄφις εἰλύεσαι καὶ ὡς δράκον συρίζησε καὶ ὡς λέων βρυχᾶσαι καὶ ὡς ἀρνίον κοιμοῦ

It is obvious that here the animal-like, ‘roaming' uterus is being exorcised... These amulets now show the Gorgon's head surrounded by fearful serpents, not, I think, to frighten the 'Hystera' away but as illustration, as her portrait. Just as knowledge of his or her real name gives the exorcist power over the demon, so does possession of the image.

The formula makes explicit that the amulets were meant to aid the 'hystera' (womb) in some way, but what is meant by hystera and what sort of aid is intended are in need of clarification. The identification of the image itself, the date and place of origin of the amulets, and the magical tradition to which they belong, are all controversial.

Many of the amulets must date from the tenth to twelfth centuries in view of their style, archaeological context, and continued use in Russia, but some scholars have suggested an earlier date for at least some examples.

Despite the literary descriptions of the demon, the identification of the image on the amulets as Abyzou is unsatisfactory. In the certain representation of this demon found on many of the amulets, namely the figure impaled by the rider, she is shown as having female form with long hair, although her body may sometimes be serpentine or animal-like. Even more significantly, the Medusa-like head on the amulets is never accompanied by a victorious rider saint, nor by an inscription in any way alluding to Abyzou or Gylou. Rather, in nearly all cases it is the hystera formula that accompanies the head.

The medieval amulets can then be placed firmly in the long tradition of belief in an animalistic womb in need of calming. According to these beliefs the womb displays some demon-like behaviour, but it cannot be equated with the Abyzou-Gylou demon.

critical_analysis.relevance: This paper is exceptionally relevant to Western Esotericism and Occultism as it provides a rigorous academic study of a well-defined magical tradition within Byzantium. It details the material culture (amulets), the specific grimoire-like textual formulae (hystera charm), and the underlying magical philosophy (roaming womb, demonology). The analysis of textual transmission, conflation of magical traditions, and the use of sympathetic imagery (womb as portrait) offers crucial insights for practitioners seeking to understand historical magical mechanics. By differentiating the hystera tradition from other contemporary amuletic practices, it illustrates the nuanced development of magical systems.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience includes academic researchers in Byzantine history, archaeology, history of medicine, and the history of magic and esotericism. It is also highly valuable for advanced practitioners of historical magic, occultists, and esotericists interested in the practical application, symbolic systems, and historical evolution of amuletic magic and ancient healing charms.
